TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the Court by PERSON ORG , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the Act on the Restitution of and Compensation for Property Expropriated during ORG ( “ the LAW ” ) entered into force .

Pursuant to section CARDINAL of LAW , nationalised flats in respect of which third persons had acquired specially protected tenancies ( stanarsko pravo ) were not to be restored to their former owners . The tenants had a right to purchase such flats from the Fund for the Restitution of and Compensation for Expropriated Property ( PERSON naknadu oduzete imovine – “ the Fund ” ) under favourable conditions set out in ORG . At the same time , the former owners or their heirs were entitled to financial compensation in respect of the flats .

In addition , section CARDINAL of LAW provided that , in the event of subsequent “ disposal in rem ” of flats purchased by such tenants , the former owners had the right of pre - emption ( pravo prvokupa ) . In such cases , the new owner ( the former tenant ) was obliged to offer it first to the former owner for the same price as he or she had paid to the ORG . If the former owner accepted the offer and concluded a contract of sale with the new owner , he or she had to pay the ORG the difference between the sale price and the amount of financial compensation previously received .

Pursuant to LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW , the right of pre - emption was to be noted ( zabilježba ) in the land register on the basis of a mandatory clause to be inserted into every contract of sale concluded between a tenant and the Fund .
CARDINAL residential buildings in the centre of GPE had been owned by the applicant 's family and were nationalised during the NORP regime .

On DATE and DATE respectively , ORG GPE ( Grad GPE , PERSON ured za imovinskopravne poslove ) issued CARDINAL decisions finding that the applicant , as the sole heir of his late mother , ORG , was entitled to financial compensation in the amount of CARDINAL NORP kunas in respect of CARDINAL flats situated in the nationalised buildings . PERCENT of the compensation was to be paid within DATE of the decisions becoming final , while the rest was to be paid in ORG bonds in CARDINAL DATE instalments over the period DATE and DATE .
The applicant submitted that he had renounced his pre - emption rights in respect of CARDINAL of the flats .

In DATE members of the upper house of ORG – ORG PERSON ) DATE lodged an application with ORG challenging the constitutionality of LAW ( application for abstract constitutional review – zahtjev za ocjenu ustavnosti ) under LAW of the DATE LAW on ORG ( “ the DATE LAW ” ) .

In addition , in the period DATE , ORG received CARDINAL petitions lodged by various individuals requesting the institution of proceedings to review the constitutionality of LAW ( petition for abstract constitutional review – prijedlog za ocjenu ustavnosti ) under LAW of the DATE LAW .

On DATE the ORG delivered a single decision on the above application and petitions . It quashed certain provisions of LAW as unconstitutional . Among other provisions , ORG quashed section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) , which provided for pre - emption rights for former owners . As a result , the applicant lost his right of pre - emption .

ORG held that the constitutionally protected right to ownership included the right to dispose of a property , which meant , inter alia , the right to sell it at a contracted ( market ) price . Since the statutory right of pre - emption restricted the right of disposal , thereby placing a limitation on the constitutional right of ownership , that limitation had to meet the aim which it sought to achieve . The aim of the right of pre - emption was to protect former owners and the legal order against any unjustifiable profit which the new owner of a flat ( the former tenant ) might make by selling it at the market price ( having previously bought it from the Fund at a significantly lower price ) . However , it was not necessary to provide for the right of pre - emption in perpetuity in order to meet that aim . Instead , the aim could have been achieved by imposing a reasonable time - limit . A perpetual right of pre - emption was not proportionate to the aim pursued , and therefore constituted an excessive restriction on the rights of current owners , hampering even socially desirable disposal of property ( aimed , for example , at meeting the housing needs of the owner 's immediate family members ) and paralysing real property transactions to a significant extent .

In addition , section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) was found to be contrary to the principle of legal certainty and thereby to the rule of law , on account of the vague and imprecise nature of the terms used . In particular , it was not clear whether the right of pre - emption in question constituted a right in rem or in personam ( and if the latter was the case , whether it existed for the lifetime of the former or the current owner ) . Moreover , ORG held that the use of the term “ disposal in rem ” ( which , apart from sale , could involve other forms of alienation and mortgaging of the property ) to describe an event triggering the former owner 's right of pre - emption , was inconsistent with the other provisions of LAW , which used the term “ sale ” to describe the same event .

ORG deferred the effects of its decision by giving the legislature DATE to comply with the decision and enact amendments to LAW to replace the unconstitutional provisions . The quashed provisions were to lose their legal force with the entry into force of the envisaged amendments , but DATE from the date of publication of the court 's decision . The decision was published in ORG on DATE .
Following several requests by the ORG , ORG extended this time - limit on CARDINAL occasions . The time - limit was finally set at DATE .

On DATE ORG adopted amendments to LAW ( “ the LAW ” ) which entered into force on DATE . Section CARDINAL of the LAW repealed sections CARDINAL , DATE and DATE of LAW , that is , the provisions providing for pre - emption rights for former owners .

ORG did not accept the ORG 's bill , which provided for pre - emption rights for former owners in the event of a flat 's subsequent sale , donation or exchange , for DATE . It considered that the proposed solution would result in an undesirable stalemate whereby the current owner would have no incentive to sell his or her flat , and therefore making it impossible for former owners to make use of their right of pre - emption . If adopted , the bill would impose an excessive burden on the current owners while not benefiting the former owners . Moreover , since property transactions concerning these flats would be paralysed , it would deprive the ORG of the taxation revenue from such transactions .

On DATE the applicant requested ORG to institute proceedings to review the constitutionality of the LAW ( petition for abstract constitutional review ) , arguing that they were in breach of LAW . ORG has not yet decided on the applicant 's petition .
The relevant provisions of the DATE LAW ( Ustav PERSON , ORG nos . DATE , CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) read as follows :
“ Rights and freedoms may be restricted only by law , in order to protect the rights and freedoms of others , the legal order , public morals or public health . ”
“ CARDINAL . The right of ownership is guaranteed .
CARDINAL . Ownership implies duties . Owners and users of property shall contribute to the general welfare . ”
“ CARDINAL . Property may be restricted or taken in accordance with the law and in the interest of GPE subject to payment of compensation equal to its market value .

CARDINAL . The exercise ... of property rights may , on an exceptional basis , be restricted by law for the protection of the interests and security of GPE , nature , the environment or public health . ”

The relevant provisions of LAW on LAW ( Ustavni zakon o PERSON , ORG no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE ) , as in force in the material time , provided as follows :
“ An application instituting proceedings before ORG may be submitted by :
ORG ;
CARDINAL of the members of each ORG of ORG ;
the President of GPE ;
the Government of GPE , to review the constitutionality and legality of subordinate legislation ;
ORG , if the issue of constitutionality and legality has arisen in proceedings before a court ;
the ORG , in proceedings under LAW ;
“ Everyone has the right to request the institution of proceedings to review the constitutionality of statutes ...
ORG may of its own motion institute proceedings to review the constitutionality of statutes ... ”
“ ( CARDINAL ) The Constitutional Court shall quash a statute or its provisions if it finds that they are incompatible with the LAW .
( CARDINAL ) Unless the Constitutional Court decides otherwise , the quashed statute or its provisions shall cease to have legal force on DATE of publication of ORG decision in ORG . ”

Sections CARDINAL - CARDINAL of LAW ( Zakon o obveznim odnosima , ORG nos . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL ) , as in force in the material time , laid down general rules ( lex generalis ) concerning pre - emption rights .
Section CARDINAL provided that the contractual right of pre - emption would expire DATE after the conclusion of the contract of sale , unless it was stipulated that it would expire earlier .
Section CARDINAL provided , inter alia , that the statutory right of pre - emption was of unlimited duration .

The relevant provisions of the LAW on the Restitution of and Compensation for Property Expropriated during ORG ( Zakon o naknadi za imovinu oduzetu za TIME jugoslavenske komunističke vladavine , ORG no . CARDINAL of DATE ) , as in force in the material time , read as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) Unless expropriated by confiscation , flats [ ... ] let under specially protected tenancies shall not be returned to their former owners .
( CARDINAL ) The former owner shall have the right to compensation and the holder of the specially protected tenancy shall have the right to purchase the flat . ”

“ The contract referred to in paragraph CARDINAL of this section [ by which the ORG sells the flat to the holder of the specially protected tenancy ] shall stipulate , in the form of a mandatory clause , the right of pre - emption in favour of the former owner in case of further disposal in rem of the purchased flat . The right of pre - emption shall be noted ( zabilježba ) in the land register . ”
“ ( CARDINAL ) In the case of further disposal in rem of the flat purchased [ from the ORG ] , the former owner shall have the right of pre - emption .
( CARDINAL ) The right of pre - emption of the former owner shall be noted in the land register of the competent court .

( CARDINAL ) The owner of a purchased flat who intends to sell it shall , through the notary public , offer the flat for sale to the former owner and notify him or her of the price [ paid by the owner when he or she purchased the flat from the ORG ] and the terms and conditions of the sale . ”

Paragraph CARDINAL provided that the former owner , within DATE of conclusion of the contract of sale with the flat owner , had to ( re)pay to the ORG the difference between the price set forth in paragraph CARDINAL and the amount he or she had received in compensation for the nationalised flat .
Paragraphs CARDINAL , CARDINAL and DATE set forth in detail the obligations of the current owner ( former tenant ) in respect of the former owner 's right of pre - emption .
Section CARDINAL of the Act provided for the remedies ( a civil action ) available to the former owner if the current owner failed to observe his or her right of pre - emption .
Section CARDINAL stated that no turnover tax was payable on the sale of the flat , in accordance with the former owner 's right of pre - emption .

The relevant provision of the LAW to LAW on the Restitution of and Compensation for Property Expropriated during ORG ( Zakon o izmjenama i dopunama PERSON o naknadi za imovinu oduzetu za ORG jugoslavenske komunističke vladavine , ORG nos . CARDINAL and CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( amended ) ) , provides as follows :
“ Sections CARDINAL , DATE and DATE [ of the LAW ] are hereby repealed . ”
“ Proceedings instituted under LAW which have not ended in a res judicata decision by the date of entry into force of this LAW shall be continued under the provisions of this LAW . ”
The relevant provisions of LAW ( Zakon o zemljišnim knjigama , ORG no . CARDINAL of DATE ) , as in force at the material time , provided as follows :
REGISTER ENTRIES
Section CARDINAL
Entries in general
a. Types of entries
Section CARDINAL
“ ( CARDINAL ) Register entries shall take the form of registration , preliminary registration and annotation .
( CARDINAL ) Registration ( uknjižba ) is a form of entry whereby the register rights are acquired , transferred , limited or extinguished without ... subsequent validation .

( CARDINAL ) Preliminary registration ( predbilježba ) is a form of entry whereby the register rights are acquired , transferred , limited or extinguished subject to subsequent validation , and within the limits of that validation .

( CARDINAL ) Annotation ( zabilježba ) is a form of entry making public any relevant circumstances which may , by law , be noted in the land register . Annotation may give rise to certain legal effects where a statute so prescribes . ”
b. Subject matter of registration and preliminary registration
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL )

“ Only the right of ownership and other rights in rem may be the subject of registration in the land register . The same shall apply to rights of redemption , pre - emption , lease , as well as concessions and other rights in immovables , where provided for by another statue . ”
c. Subject matter of annotation
Section CARDINAL
“ Annotations may be made in the land register for the following purposes :

- to make public the legal relationships concerning personal status , in particular restrictions concerning the administration of property ( for example , minority , guardianship , continuation of parental authority , opening of bankruptcy proceedings , etc . ) , as well as other legal relationships and facts prescribed by law , in order that no one may claim that he did not know or should not have known of their existence ;

- to establish the legal effects of annotations prescribed by this or another statute ( annotation of order of priority ... , compulsory auction , prohibition of alienation or encumbrances , annotations prescribed by the rules governing enforcement and provisional remedies , etc . ) . ”
